Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Identification of Key Dynamics for Rumor Spread and Control during Hurricanes Harvey and Irma

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
Forms of social media like Twitter are increasingly relied upon by members of the public as sources of information in emergencies like hurricanes and floods. The downside of these sources of information is that they may also be the source of unfounded rumors as were spread regarding a host of issues during hurricanes Harvey and Irma. The instant sharing features of social media make rumors difficult to control because information from official sources to debunk misinformation often comes late. Motivated by those issue, this project will collect and analyze data related to how rumors were spread and controlled during Hurricane Harvey and Hurricane Irma. The objectives of this project are to study (a) how rumor spreads on social media; (b) what effective debunking network constitutes; and (c) how the public deals with risk information that stipulates subsequent communication behaviors such as information processing and sharing.

The study will use social network analysis, content analysis, survey, interviews, optimization and simulation, to (a) identify rumor response behaviors of social media users during disasters; (b) identify motivations behind social media users' risk communication behaviors such as information processing and information sharing; (c) build a decision making model of individual social media users to predict future responses to rumors; (d) investigate social media usage in rumor control and potential collaborations among disaster response agencies in rumor management; and (e) design potential collaboration methods among disaster response agencies on social media to minimize the costs and damages generated by rumors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major research goals of this project are to study (a) how rumor spreads on social media; (b) what effective debunking network constitutes; and (c) how the general public deals with risk information that stipulates subsequent communication behaviors such as information processing and sharing. In particular, this study uses social network analysis, content analysis, survey, interviews, optimization and simulation, to (a) identify rumor response behaviors of social media users during disasters; (b) identify motivations behind social media users? risk communication behaviors such as information processing and information sharing; (c) build a decision making model of individual social media users to predict future responses to rumors; (d) investigate social media usage in rumor control and potential collaborations among disaster response agencies in rumor management; and (e) design potential collaboration methods among disaster response agencies on social media to minimize the costs and damages generated by rumors.

In this project, we investigate the dissemination features of rumor debunking/spreading on Twitter during natural disasters, including: rumor life span, debunking effectiveness and the cross-platform sourcing and sharing behaviors that Twitter users exhibit. The false rumor "immigration status is checked at shelters" spread in both Hurricane Harvey and Hurricane Irma in 2017, and was analyzed based on a collection of 12,900 selected tweets. By studying the rumor control efforts made by two official accounts from local city governments, we found that 13% of the debunkers utilized (cited, mentioned, paraphrased) the official information in new tweets to help mitigate the rumor. We also found that after these official debunking posts, the presence of debunkers compared to spreaders increased by an average of 133%. Results on sourcing analysis show that less than 25% of the information sources that Twitter users cited when posting tweets came from Twitter itself, and the majority of sources came from traditional websites. This research provides some novel insights into the effectiveness of rumor control efforts made through social media during natural disasters, and also the information sourcing and sharing behaviors that users exhibit during the spreading and debunking of rumors and misinformation.

In this project, we also analyze how features of a rumor tweet (i.e., source credibility and social credibility cues) influence people?s credibility perception and intention to share the tweet. We contribute to the development of future training data for machine learning programs and inform social media users on how to exercise caution when judging the veracity and credibility of information on social media. Results of an experimental survey based on a nationally representative sample showed that the presence of source credibility and social credibility cues influence individuals? credibility perception of a rumor tweet, which subsequently affect their intentions to share the tweet with others. While source credibility cues are effective in increasing credibility perception, social credibility cues based on the number of likes, comments, and retweets actually make participants view the tweet as less credible. Further, controlling for individual characteristics and risk perception, sadness is positively related to credibility perception and anger is positively related to sharing intention. Controlling for risk perceptions and emotions, those who view the rumor tweet as credible are more likely to share it with others, which demonstrate the importance of source credibility in influencing the way in which people deal with misinformation on social media. 

This research represents a joint effort between industrial and systems engineering and communication scholars, which offers a unique blend of macro, system-level perspective and micro, individual-based approach to research. Data collected from this project would offer both scholars and emergency responders meaningful pathways to navigate through the information landscape surrounding large-scale disasters. Findings from this research would also shed light on how individual social media users can make more informed decisions about the information they encounter on social media during crisis. 

Several conference presentations were made by several students (graduate and undergraduate students) supported by this project. The research team includes female Ph.D. and undergraduate students in Engineering. The research results would provide practical and testable insight into future rumor response, control and debunking operations across the United States and elsewhere in the world.
